repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
I added tests for all versions of python to windows and solved some problems to let them work, but some don't:
2.7, 3.4 - since no suitable compiler version is installed
3.9 - inline, details: #3450, #4379
3.5 - one cpp-only test fails, [output](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4324#discussion_r709984107)

I also uncommented the coverage tests and added some code to the .sh to make them work. They work for a decent amount of time, which is the opposite of what was said in the comments.

If anyone wants to try to fix the problems and run 2.7 (and maybe 3.4), then you will need to use [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/67642436), probably relying on both versions of [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/10558328).

comment_data.body: probably there's need to change the comment
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -196,15 +196,30 @@ jobs:
             backend: cpp
             env: { MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET: 10.14 }
 
+        exclude:
+          # fails github.com/cython/cython/issues/3450
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 3.9
+
+          # fails due to lack of a compatible compiler
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 2.7
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 3.4
+
+          # cpp specific test fails
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 3.5
+            backend: cpp
+
     # This defaults to 360 minutes (6h) which is way too long and if a test gets stuck, it can block other pipelines.
     # From testing, the runs tend to take ~20 minutes, so a limit of 30 minutes should be enough. This can always be
     # changed in the future if needed.
-    timeout-minutes: 30
+    timeout-minutes: 60

comment_data.body: `/W4` is recommended and gives an adequate number of warnings, but we can use `/Wall` + ignore unnecessary warnings (additionally to those `/wd`s)

+  fi
+

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  # /wd disables warnings
  # 4711 warns that function `x` was selected for automatic inline expansion
  # 4127 warns that a conditional expression is constant, should be fixed here https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4317
  # (off by default) 5045 warns that the compiler will insert Spectre mitigations for memory load if the /Qspectre switch is specified
  # (off by default) 4820 warns about the code in Python\3.9.6\x64\include ...
  WARNARGS="/W4 /wd4711 /wd4127 /wd5045 /wd4820"
```

comment_data.body:
Probably rather <1.16 – that seems to be the version where they ended Py3.4 support.
```suggestion
numpy<1.16.0
```
Seems to be a general issue, though, and doesn't belong into a PR to make Windows builds work.
Otherwise a lot of windows cpp tests fail

comment_data.body:
here are all the use cases:

`CFLAGS="-O2 $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
`CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO" $PYTHON_DBG`
`CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`

I do not see a better solution than adding `DEBUG_INFO` to `CFLAGS`, and then we will have to write like this:

`CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -O2 $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
`CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION" $PYTHON_DBG`
`CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`

Not much better ..

comment_data.body:
> > I'd rather expect a change like this in a separate PR.
> 
> Well, if you want .. but it seems easier to fix failing tests right here, in the place where i add them

The problem is not new in this PR, is it? It's already there, and appveyor probably isn't happy with it either. Making it a part of this PR means that it will be buried under a heap of CI config related changes in the git history and for later generations of developers (and my future self and maybe yours), it will be difficult to understand why this was done at the time. Let's be nice to the people who live in the future.

comment_data.body:
> here are all the use cases:
> 
> `CFLAGS="-O2 $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
> `CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO" $PYTHON_DBG`
> `CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`
> 
> I do not see a better solution than adding `DEBUG_INFO` to `CFLAGS`, and then we will have to write like this:
> 
> `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -O2 $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
> `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION" $PYTHON_DBG`
> `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`
> 
> Not much better ..

I think it's time to clean this up.

We can always add `$WARNARGS` and `$DEBUG_INFO` globally to `CFLAGS` since it doesn't hurt.

`-O2` can go to the end, then it's just `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -O2" python setup.py …`. We can then add `-O0` or `-Og` to `CFLAGS` by default.

AFAICT, that leaves two cases where we add a single additional option. I think that's more than bearable.

comment_data.body: Yes, I translated this incorrectly to the new syntax. But then it will be triggered only for cpython 3.10-dev (all non `-dev` versions are cut off by earlier `$PYTHON_VERSION == *"-dev"` and we add `COVERAGE = 1` only on cpython  3.7 and 3.9) is it the correct behavior?

commit 1461e514c00056eef58c7c18262012b1510ba692
Author: Stefan Behnel <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
Date:   Mon Oct 25 14:29:02 2021 +0200

    Clean up the NumPy integration test by moving the doctests into the functions that they test.

commit 68bb7164d4f93573c4e6a7249561b742818b39cb
Author: Stefan Behnel <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
Date:   Mon Oct 25 14:14:24 2021 +0200

    Remove dead test code.

commit 4a7467892bb60f9381b5c548d4600804c983c5d1
Author: Stefan Behnel <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
Date:   Sun Oct 24 21:27:44 2021 +0200

    Use newer test dependencies in Py3.6+. (Excluding 3.10 for now to give the projects a bit more time.)

commit 9d1ffd5dcdcc0f2f719f86a9a30ce08a67641f10
Author: da-woods <dw-git@d-woods.co.uk>
Date:   Sun Oct 24 23:13:50 2021 +0100

    Initial support for Python 3.11 (GH-4414)

    * Add a basic replacement for PyCode_New().

    An optimized versions would be nice, but this is intended to work sufficiently to start testing. Also, CPython 3.11 might actually add a new C-API function to simplify setting the current code position. That might be used instead.

    * Disable introspection of frame object with vectorcall

    This feature looked to only be used for early Python versions that don't have the full vectorcall protocol (and the contents of the frame object are changed in Python 3.11).

commit 346c81fe9b0a13892a2dbd137d994f198940b435
Author: Stefan Behnel <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
Date:   Sun Oct 24 21:18:10 2021 +0200

    Make sure that version dependent special methods are correctly and completely excluded via preprocessor guards.
    Previously, implementing "__div__" could fail in Py3 (if the code for adapting the Python wrapper was generated) or would at least generate C compiler warnings about unused "__div__" C functions.

commit cbddad23e30ea6d31e0178a4c623f1f6d75452c3
Author: Victor Stinner <vstinner@python.org>
Date:   Mon Oct 18 12:03:17 2021 +0200

    Make Profile.c use PyThreadState_EnterTracing() (GH-4411)

    Instead of __Pyx_SetTracing(), Profile.c now uses PyThreadState_EnterTracing() and PyThreadState_LeaveTracing(), which were added to Python 3.11.0a2:
    https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/28542

    When these functions are used, Cython no longer sets directly PyThreadState.cframe.use_tracing.

commit f6eeeda534dd1139a7ea35bfa627db1789082b06
Author: da-woods <dw-git@d-woods.co.uk>
Date:   Sun Oct 17 19:01:52 2021 +0100

    Fix fused cpdef default arguments (GH-4413)

    A couple of things were going wrong:
    * they're creating CloneNodes (but not requiring the contents of the clone of the clone node to be temp)
    * assignment from a clone node generates cleanup code (which is against the general rules of a clone node), and also loses a reference via giveref
    * cpdef functions cause a small memory leak (#4412) by assigning to their constants twice. This is unfortunately difficult to test for. With this patch we no longer leak, but still duplicate a little bit of work.

    Improve "import_array" guard (GH-4397)

    Stop using NPY_NDARRAYOBJECT_H since:
    a) in principle it's private
    b) Numpy has renamed it
    and use a public symbol instead.

    I think the existing tests are adequate - we just aren't yet testing
    against a new enough version of Numpy to have caught it yet.

    Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4396
    Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4394

    Handle function "outer_attrs" more consistently (GH-4375)

    A few children of function nodes need to be consistently evaluated
    outside the function scope. This PR attempts to do so and thus
    fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4367.

     Fix the name of attributes in the common ABI module  (GH-4376)

commit fa8db66368a9527c8df441a0bbfee714eb795930
Author: da-woods <dw-git@d-woods.co.uk>

    Avoid AddTraceback() if stringtab isn't set up (GH-4378)

    This can happen (rarely) with exceptions that occur very early in the module init process.

    Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4377

    Uses a fake Numpy module for testing to make a version of "import_array" that always fails.

commit f94f26a073ee5c9987ccab6acb87ad453c6ec625
Author: da-woods <dw-git@d-woods.co.uk>
Date:   Mon Sep 27 09:58:20 2021 +0100

    Make __Pyx_CoroutineAwaitType non-pickleable (GH-4381)

    This is explicitly tested for: https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aea4e6b84b38223c540266f8c57093ee2039f284/tests/run/test_coroutines_pep492.pyx#L2400

    It turns out some earlier versions of Python assume that
    C-API classes without a dict or slot are pickleable by the class
    name. Currently it isn't pickleable because the class name lookup
    is failing but this change makes it more robust.

    See https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4376

commit 740305526a702f08e462f20a8ba6f9013126f330
Author: da-woods <dw-git@d-woods.co.uk>
